Detail.content_title: District 6 Community Coffee will give residents first look at new Chisholm Trail Community Center
Detail.content_teaser: Mayor Betsy Price and Councilmember Jungus Jordan will host a JavaFW Caffeinated Town Hall meeting on Saturday, Feb. 1, at 9 a.m. at the Chisholm Trail Community Center, 4680 McPherson Blvd.
Detail.content_html:
District 6 Community Coffee will give residents first look at new Chisholm Trail Community Center

Posted Jan. 27, 2014

Mayor Betsy Price and Councilmember Jordan will host a community town hall on Saturday.

Mayor Betsy Price and Councilmember Jungus Jordan will host a JavaFW Caffeinated Town Hall meeting 9 a.m. Saturday, Feb. 1, at the Chisholm Trail Community Center, 4680 McPherson Blvd.

Residents in attendance will be the first to get a sneak peek of the new community center. All are welcome to attend the meeting and discuss issues and concerns related to their neighborhoods, their communities and their Fort Worth.

For more information, contact Jamie Wilson at 817-392-8806.

Detail.content_title: The T names TRE chief, grants administrator
Detail.content_teaser: The T named Tom Tulley chief operating officer of the Trinity Railway Express and William Johnson as The T’s grants and disadvantaged business enterprise administrator.
Detail.content_html:
The T names TRE chief, grants administrator

Posted Jan. 28, 2014

Tom Tulley

The Fort Worth Transportation Authority (The T) named Tom Tulley chief operating officer of the Trinity Railway Express (TRE), jointly owned and operated by The T and Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), and William Johnson as The T’s grants and disadvantaged business enterprise administrator.

Tulley was passenger rail specialist for the Federal Railroad Administration Region 5 in Dallas from 1999-2012. He fills a restructured chief operating officer position that now also assumes the role of chief mechanical officer. These positions were consolidated since each oversees overlapping functions of TRE’s contract operator.

William Johnson

Johnson had been assistant director of the City of Fort Worth Housing and Economic Development Department since 2008, where he was primary adviser on design and implementation of its Minority and Women Business Enterprise Ordinance and Disadvantaged Business Enterprise Program. He also oversaw the city’s Business Assistance Center, which is responsible for providing training and counseling to small businesses.

Detail.content_teaser: The city’s neighborhood community centers are calling all ghosts and goblins, pixies and fairies, family and friends to celebrate the season.
Detail.content_html:
Community centers plan fall festivities

Posted Oct. 8, 2012

Photo courtesy of Daryl Marling.

Other Events

Don't forget to check out these events at some of Fort Worth's other attractions.

Oct. 13: Frontier Fall Fest

Oct. 19-21, 26-28: Boo at the Zoo.

Oct. 25: Trails and Treats at the Nature Center and Refuge.

Oct. 27: Fall Festival in the Japanese Garden.

The city’s neighborhood community centers are calling all ghosts and goblins, pixies and fairies, family and friends to celebrate the season.

It’s fall festival season and each center has its own variety of activities, games, contests, and prizes. Whether it’s the haunted house at Highland Hills, karaoke at Riverside or the magician at Northside, each center offers entertainment in a safe environment.

“In our community, it is a matter of safety for our kids,” said Carol Brown, Como Community Center supervisor.

Visit your community center to learn more about their fall programs and opportunities.
